metadata.title: Texas Security Deposit Rules Knowledge Base
metadata.source: Texas Property Code Chapter 92, Subchapter C
metadata.purpose: Deterministic population of Case Analysis Report sections

92.101.title: Security Deposit
92.101.summary: Defines what constitutes a security deposit under Texas law.
key_provisions: A security deposit is any advance of money, other than a rental application deposit or an advance payment of rent, intended to secure performance of a residential lease.

92.102.title: Applicability
92.102.summary: Specifies that this subchapter applies to all residential leases.
key_provisions: Applies to security deposits made under residential leases.

92.103.title: Obligation to Refund
92.103.summary: Establishes the 30-day timeline for returning deposits or providing itemization.
key_provisions: Landlord shall refund security deposit within 30 days after tenant surrenders premises.
The 30-day period begins when tenant provides written statement of forwarding address.
If deductions are made, landlord must provide written description and itemized list.

subsections.a: Refund obligation within 30 days of surrender and forwarding address
subsections.b: Written itemization required if deductions made

92.104.title: Retention of Security Deposit; Accounting
92.104.summary: Specifies permissible reasons for retaining a security deposit.
key_provisions: Landlord may retain deposit for damages and charges for which tenant is legally liable under the lease.
Landlord may not retain deposit for normal wear and tear.
Landlord may retain for unpaid rent.

92.105.title: Cessation of Owner's Interest
92.105.summary: Addresses transfer of deposit obligations when property ownership changes.
key_provisions: New owner liable for return of deposit whether or not received from previous owner.
Previous owner remains liable until deposit transferred or tenant notified of new owner.

92.106.title: Records
92.106.summary: Requires landlords to maintain records of security deposits.
key_provisions: Landlord shall keep accurate records of all security deposits.

92.107.title: Tenant's Forwarding Address
92.107.summary: Addresses the requirement for tenant to provide forwarding address.
key_provisions: Tenant's failure to provide forwarding address does not forfeit right to deposit refund.
Landlord's duty to refund does not mature until forwarding address is provided.

92.108.title: Liability for Withholding Last Month's Rent
92.108.summary: Addresses tenant liability for using deposit as last month's rent without consent.
key_provisions: Tenant may not withhold rent for last period claiming deposit covers it, unless landlord agrees.

92.109.title: Liability of Landlord
92.109.summary: Establishes landlord liability for bad faith retention of deposits.
key_provisions: Landlord who in bad faith retains deposit may be liable for amount wrongfully withheld plus $100 plus three times the deposit wrongfully withheld plus reasonable attorney's fees.

subsections.a: Presumption of bad faith if landlord fails to return deposit or provide itemization within 30 days

yes.basis_template: Tenant indicated the security deposit was returned in full.

no.basis_template: Tenant indicated the security deposit was not returned.

partial.basis_template: Tenant indicated the security deposit was partially returned. Amount returned: {amount_returned}.

yes.basis_template: Tenant indicated an itemized list of deductions was received on {date_itemized_list_received}.

no.basis_template: Tenant indicated no itemized list of deductions was received.

unknown.basis_template: Tenant indicated uncertainty about whether an itemized list was received.

true.basis_template: Based on dates provided, tenant received refund or itemization within the 30-day period commonly referenced in Texas guidance.

false.basis_template: Based on dates provided, {days_since_move_out} days have passed since move-out. Tenant has not received full refund or itemized list.

unknown.basis_template: Cannot determine timeline compliance; required dates not provided.

yes.basis_template: Tenant indicated a forwarding address was provided{forwarding_date_clause}.

no.basis_template: Tenant indicated a forwarding address was not provided. Note: Per publicly available Texas guidance, the 30-day timeline may not begin until forwarding address is provided.

unknown.basis_template: Tenant indicated uncertainty about whether a forwarding address was provided.

true.basis_template: Itemized list was received within 30 days of move-out date.

false.basis_template: Itemized list was received {days_to_itemization} days after move-out, exceeding the 30-day period commonly referenced in Texas guidance.

not_applicable.basis_template: No itemized list was received; this check is not applicable.

unknown.basis_template: Cannot determine; itemization receipt date not provided.

leverage_point_rules.title: 30-day timeline observation (no refund)
leverage_point_rules.observation_template: According to the dates provided, more than 30 days ({days_since_move_out} days) have passed since the stated move-out date. The tenant indicates the security deposit has not been returned.
leverage_point_rules.statutory_context: Publicly available Texas guidance commonly references a 30-day timeline for deposit refund or itemization. See Tex. Prop. Code § 92.103.

leverage_point_rules.title: 30-day timeline observation (no itemization)
leverage_point_rules.observation_template: According to the dates provided, more than 30 days have passed since move-out. The tenant indicates no itemized list of deductions has been received despite partial or no return of the deposit.
leverage_point_rules.statutory_context: When deductions are made from a security deposit, publicly available Texas guidance references a requirement to provide an itemized list. See Tex. Prop. Code § 92.104(b).

leverage_point_rules.title: Partial return without itemization
leverage_point_rules.observation_template: The tenant indicates the security deposit was partially returned (amount: {amount_returned}) but no itemized list of deductions was provided.
leverage_point_rules.statutory_context: Publicly available Texas guidance references a requirement to provide written itemization when deductions are made from a security deposit. See Tex. Prop. Code § 92.104(b).

leverage_point_rules.title: Forwarding address and timeline
leverage_point_rules.observation_template: The tenant indicates a forwarding address was not provided to the landlord. According to publicly available Texas guidance, the 30-day refund timeline may not begin until a forwarding address is provided in writing.
leverage_point_rules.statutory_context: Publicly available Texas guidance indicates that a tenant's failure to provide a forwarding address does not forfeit the right to a refund, but the landlord's obligation to refund may not mature until the address is provided. See Tex. Prop. Code § 92.107.

leverage_point_rules.title: Lease clause timeline observation
leverage_point_rules.observation_template: The uploaded lease appears to reference a {lease_timeline_days}-day timeline for deposit return. Publicly available Texas guidance commonly references a 30-day timeline.
leverage_point_rules.statutory_context: Publicly available Texas guidance references a 30-day timeline. Lease clauses that conflict with statutory requirements may not supersede them. See Tex. Prop. Code § 92.103.

leverage_point_rules.title: Written communication record
leverage_point_rules.observation_template: The tenant indicates written communication ({communication_methods}) was used after move-out. Written records may be useful for documentation purposes.

leverage_point_rules.title: Potential normal wear and tear observation
leverage_point_rules.observation_template: The tenant's notes reference terms that may relate to normal wear and tear. Publicly available Texas guidance indicates that landlords may not retain deposits for normal wear and tear.

supporting_facts_template.fact: Tenant notes mention: wear/tear/normal use concerns

leverage_point_rules.statutory_context: Publicly available Texas guidance indicates that a landlord may not retain a security deposit for normal wear and tear. See Tex. Prop. Code § 92.104.

statutory_reference_rules.title: Obligation to Refund
statutory_reference_rules.summary: This section addresses the general timeline for return of security deposits and provision of itemization.

include_when.reason: Core statute for all security deposit matters.

statutory_reference_rules.relevance_template: Referenced because the tenant's situation involves a security deposit and timeline questions.

statutory_reference_rules.title: Retention of Security Deposit; Accounting
statutory_reference_rules.summary: This section addresses permissible reasons for retaining a security deposit and the requirement for itemization.
statutory_reference_rules.relevance_template: Referenced because the tenant indicates the deposit was not fully returned.

statutory_reference_rules.title: Tenant's Forwarding Address
statutory_reference_rules.summary: This section addresses the relationship between providing a forwarding address and the refund timeline.
statutory_reference_rules.relevance_template: Referenced because the tenant's forwarding address status may affect timeline calculations.

statutory_reference_rules.title: Liability of Landlord
statutory_reference_rules.summary: This section addresses potential landlord liability in security deposit matters.
statutory_reference_rules.relevance_template: Referenced because publicly available Texas guidance addresses landlord liability when the 30-day timeline has passed without refund or itemization.

statutory_reference_rules.title: Security Deposit
statutory_reference_rules.summary: This section defines what constitutes a security deposit under Texas law.

include_when.reason: Foundational definition for security deposit matters.

statutory_reference_rules.relevance_template: Referenced as the foundational definition of security deposits in Texas.

procedural_step_rules.title: Gather lease documentation
procedural_step_rules.description: Some tenants choose to gather copies of their signed lease agreement, including any amendments or addenda, for their records.

procedural_step_rules.title: Gather deposit payment records
procedural_step_rules.description: Some tenants choose to gather proof of the security deposit payment, such as bank records, canceled checks, or receipts.

procedural_step_rules.title: Gather move-out documentation
procedural_step_rules.description: Some tenants choose to gather move-out inspection reports, photos of the property at move-out, and any forwarding address documentation.

procedural_step_rules.title: Gather communication records
procedural_step_rules.description: Some tenants choose to compile copies of all written communications with the landlord regarding the security deposit, including emails, texts, and letters.

procedural_step_rules.title: Provide forwarding address in writing
procedural_step_rules.description: According to publicly available Texas guidance, a tenant may provide a written forwarding address to the landlord. Some tenants choose to do this via certified mail with return receipt to create a record.
procedural_step_rules.applicability_note: Relevant if a forwarding address has not yet been provided to the landlord.

procedural_step_rules.title: Send written correspondence
procedural_step_rules.description: Some tenants choose to send written correspondence to their landlord documenting the facts of their situation, including dates, amounts, and a request for the deposit refund or itemized deduction list. This is not a demand letter.
procedural_step_rules.applicability_note: Relevant if the deposit has not been fully returned.

procedural_step_rules.title: Consult a licensed Texas attorney
procedural_step_rules.description: A licensed Texas attorney can provide legal advice specific to individual circumstances. The State Bar of Texas provides a lawyer referral service.

resources.title: State Bar of Texas Lawyer Referral
resources.description: Official lawyer referral service provided by the State Bar of Texas.

procedural_step_rules.title: Learn about small claims court
procedural_step_rules.description: Texas Justice of the Peace courts handle small claims matters up to $20,000. Information about filing procedures is available through local JP courts. This is informational only and not a recommendation to file.

resources.title: Texas Justice Courts
resources.description: Information about Texas Justice of the Peace courts.

resources.title: TexasLawHelp.org - Small Claims
resources.description: Free legal information about small claims procedures in Texas.

procedural_step_rules.applicability_note: Informational resource if the 30-day timeline has passed without resolution.

items.label: Photos of property at move-in (for comparison)

deadline_computation_rules.label: General 30-day timeline reference (from move-out)
deadline_computation_rules.notes: This is the general timeline commonly referenced in Texas guidance. The actual trigger may depend on when a forwarding address was provided.

deadline_computation_rules.label: General 30-day timeline reference (from forwarding address)
deadline_computation_rules.notes: According to publicly available Texas guidance, the 30-day period may run from when the tenant provides a forwarding address in writing.
